pos_items.definition: male and female cows kept on a farm for their milk or meat
dictionary_examples: beef/dairy cattle
learner_examples: He was born in Australia, where his father has a big cattle station. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: items such as shirts, dresses and trousers that you wear on your body
dictionary_examples: She wears smart/casual clothes.
I'm just putting my clothes on.
Take your clothes off and get in the bath, Holly.
a clothes shop
learner_examples: And she likes to wear new clothes. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Russian)

pos_items.definition: although
dictionary_examples: He tried, albeit without success.
learner_examples: If and when homework, household chores and social duties had been dealt with, we were free to pursue our own designs, albeit usually hampered by a younger child tagging along. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: used to join two words, phrases, parts of sentences or related statements together
dictionary_examples: Ann and Jim
knives and forks
We kissed and hugged each other.
Tidy up your room. And don't forget to make your bed!
learner_examples: I have got [a] nice bed, [a] mirror, [a] sofa and a table. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak)

pos_items.definition: used to say that one thing happens after another thing
dictionary_examples: I got dressed and had my breakfast.
learner_examples: I get up early [in the] morning and I have breakfast. [T]hen I go to college. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Somali)

pos_items.definition: used when saying or adding numbers
dictionary_examples: It cost a hundred and twenty pounds.
Two and three equals five.
learner_examples: It's about two and a half hours. (Key English Test; A2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used instead of 'to' after some verbs, such as 'try' and 'go'
dictionary_examples: Try and eat something.

learner_examples: I hope [to] go and see Disneyland. (Key English Test; A2; French)

learner_examples: I like watching television, playing [on] the computer, reading book[s] and so on. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

She's not only a painter but also a writer.

learner_examples: There are eight rooms but the best one is my bedroom, because there are a lot of books. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used before you say why something did not happen or is not true

learner_examples: I'm really sorry I haven't written for so long, but I was very busy last week. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: except
dictionary_examples: Everyone but Andrew knows.

learner_examples: I'm free all days of the week but Monday and Wednesday. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: also
dictionary_examples: Are you going to invite Steve as well?
learner_examples: Dylma goes to school every day and work[s] as well. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in addition to
dictionary_examples: There are soft drinks as well as coffee and tea.
They have lived in the United States as well as Britain.
learner_examples: I like pop as well as country music. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: having a particular use
dictionary_examples: We used the box as a table.
learner_examples: It is very useful because you can use it as a camera. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to compare two things, people, amounts, etc.
dictionary_examples: She'll soon be as tall as her mother.
I can't run as fast as you.
The food here isn't as good as it used to be.
She earns three times as much as I do.
learner_examples: The air isn't as good as in the countryside because of the pollution. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: as much/quickly/soon, etc. as something can happen or be done
dictionary_examples: Please sit down as quickly as possible.
I'll go as soon as possible.
learner_examples: I need it as soon as possible. (Key English Test; A2; Malay)

pos_items.definition: in the way that happens most of the time
dictionary_examples: As usual, James was the last to arrive.
learner_examples: As usual, I'll travel by plane. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: being or appearing to be a particular thing
dictionary_examples: He was dressed as a pirate.
As a young man, he was very lonely.
learner_examples: She was there, standing in front of me, still dressed as a bride, with tears in her eyes. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: at the same time or a very short time after
dictionary_examples: As soon as I saw her, I knew there was something wrong.
learner_examples: As soon as the rain stopped, I called my friend and we all continued walking in the park, and we all enjoyed ourselves. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Georgian)

pos_items.definition: used at the beginning of a sentence to introduce a slightly different subject, but one that is connected in some way
dictionary_examples: I was pleased about the news. As for Emily, well, who cares what she thinks?
learner_examples: As for Chris, he agreed with me to do fifty kilometres on Saturday and stay at the Lakeside Inn. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: because of something
dictionary_examples: Unemployment has risen as a result of the credit crunch.
learner_examples: [O]n more than one oc[c]asion I missed the new releases or arrived late, as a result of trusting the [cinema's] website. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: when considered as a group and not in parts
dictionary_examples: The population as a whole is getting healthier.
learner_examples: To sum up, I can say that the greatest ever invention is the invention of computers, that has affected both indivi[d]uals and society as a whole. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: used to give more information, or to correct something that has been said
dictionary_examples: John plays golf professionally. As a matter of fact, he has just won a big competition.
"So you're from Cambridge?" "No, as a matter of fact, I'm from Bristol."
learner_examples: I think it would be better to choose somewhere outdoors. As a matter of fact, I prefer the open air and the sunlight! (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used to introduce a list or description
dictionary_examples: The main reasons are as follows.
learner_examples: The summary of relevant points and recommendations are as follows: 1. Both of them are located in the centre of town. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: something that you say in order to introduce a surprising fact
dictionary_examples: As it happens, her birthday is the day after mine.
learner_examples: As it happens, I am currrently looking for a computer course for myself and I would like to join one of your courses. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Hebrew)

pos_items.definition: used before a number or amount to show that the number or amount is large
dictionary_examples: As many as 6,000 people may have been infected with the disease.
learner_examples: As many as 90% of them went to [the] cinema on a regular basis in 1990, with the peak of [a] 95% attendance rate taking place in 1996. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Thai)

pos_items.definition: used to say that two things are very different
dictionary_examples: I'm talking about English football, as opposed to European football.
learner_examples: Love is accepting people as they are, being tolerant and giving freedom, as opposed to possessive love, which is what is often - if not always - understood by love. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.sense_title: do sth as you see/think fit
pos_items.definition: to do something that you feel is the right thing to do, although other people might disapprove
dictionary_examples: You must spend the money as you see fit.
learner_examples: Do as you think fit! (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to show that the name of something tells you something about it
dictionary_examples: The Long Room, as its name implies, runs the entire length of the house.
learner_examples: Sour Sweet, as the name implies, is originally a Chinese restaurant. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: as something is now, without changes in it
dictionary_examples: The law as it stands is very unclear.
learner_examples: In my opinion, this debate is rooted in a deeper questioning of society's foundations: some people see society as it stands today as inherently flawed, an amorphous group of people who follow and worship anyone that gives them pleasure. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to describe how a situation seems to be
dictionary_examples: It looks as if it might rain.
It was as though we had known each other for years.
learner_examples: Everything was so familiar, as though he [had] never left the place. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.sense_title: as far as sb is concerned
pos_items.definition: used to show what someone thinks about something
dictionary_examples: As far as I'm concerned, feng shui is a load of rubbish.
As far as our customers are concerned, price is the main consideration.
learner_examples: As far as Laura was concerned, he was the most disgusting man in the world. (First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish)

pos_items.sense_title: as far as sth is concerned
pos_items.definition: used to tell someone what you are talking about
dictionary_examples: As far as money is concerned, we're doing very well.
learner_examples: First of all, I think the Majestic Hotel would be the right location, but I have doubts as far as the costs are concerned. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something must happen before something else can happen
dictionary_examples: I can come as long as I can leave by 4.00.
Bring your friends by all means - just as long as I know how many are coming.
learner_examples: The colo[u]rs I wear are not important, as long as I don't wear any pink clothes. I really dislike that colo[u]r. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that you think something is true, but cannot be sure
dictionary_examples: As far as I know, he's never been in trouble with the police.
learner_examples: As far as I know, accommodation at Camp California is in tents or log cabins. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: until and including this time
dictionary_examples: We haven't needed extra staff as yet, but may do in the future.
No ambulances had as yet managed to get across the river.
learner_examples: I would like to do something about it, but as I can't imagine building anything near my beautiful house (because I'm afraid it would destroy its wonderful harmony), I have no idea as yet how to solve this problem. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: because
dictionary_examples: As it was getting late, I decided to book into a hotel.
You can go first as you're the oldest.
learner_examples: I need it as I have to return it to the library. (Key English Test; A2; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: while or during the time that
dictionary_examples: I saw him as I was coming into the building.
He gets more attractive as he gets older.
learner_examples: After spending two hours searching for her I started to feel desperate, but just as I was ready to give up, the sky got normal again and I found myself [at] my own wedding and she was my wife! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: in the same way
dictionary_examples: He got divorced, (just) as his parents had done years before.
This year, as in previous years, tickets sold very quickly.
As with his earlier movies, the special effects in his latest film are brilliant.
learner_examples: As we expected, we are going to see a movie tonight. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: but
dictionary_examples: He's coming to see us this evening, although I don't know exactly when.
He's rather shy, although he's not as bad as he used to be.
learner_examples: I liked the food although my friends didn't like it. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: despite the fact that
dictionary_examples: She walked home by herself, although she knew that it was dangerous.
learner_examples: There were no taxis on the street so, although it was raining, I started walking in the rain. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: If something closes, it moves so that it is not open, and if you close something, you make it move so that it is not open.
dictionary_examples: Could you close the door/window please?
Close your eyes - I've got a surprise for you.
learner_examples: It's [a] Motorola mobile phone. It's pink and you can open and close it. (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: When a shop, restaurant or public place closes, people cannot go into it.
dictionary_examples: The banks had closed so I couldn't get any money out.
The museum closes at 5.30.
learner_examples: Well you have to be here in my house at 1pm, because the sports centre opens at 1.30pm and closes at 4pm. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: If a business or organization closes, or if someone or something closes it, it stops operating.
dictionary_examples: The factory closed over ten years ago.
A lot of restaurants/shops are closing because they can't afford to pay the rent.
learner_examples: In addition, I would like you to know that the Hotel Astrid closed last year. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: to end, or to end something
dictionary_examples: She closed the meeting with a short speech.
learner_examples: That's how you should close the exhibition: with a question. How much further can Arnold go? (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: near in distance, position or time
dictionary_examples: His house is close to the sea.
Don't get too close to the dog, Rosie.
It was close to lunchtime when we arrived.
learner_examples: It's close to my house. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Urdu)

pos_items.definition: describes people who know each other very well and like each other a lot, or who see and talk to each other a lot
dictionary_examples: Mira is one of my closest friends.
Her relationship isn't good with her father, but she's very close to her mother.
My brother and I have become much closer over the years.
learner_examples: That night, we had just my family and some of my close friends. (Key English Test; A2; Thai)

pos_items.definition: A close relative is someone who is directly related to you, for example, your mother, father or brother.
dictionary_examples: There weren't many people at the funeral - just close family/relatives.
learner_examples: Tomson has [a] close family, his son lives with them, [and] his company makes a good profit. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: having only a small difference
dictionary_examples: The election results were so close they had to vote again.
He came second in the race, but it was very close.
The youngest boys are so close in age they look like twins.
learner_examples: The over-grazing, the deforestation and the over-cultivation [seem] to be the main causes of the degradation of the agricultural land, the percentages being quite close in value. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Romanian)

pos_items.definition: seeing or communicating with someone a lot
dictionary_examples: I'm still in close contact with my school friends.
Our school has close links with a school in China.
learner_examples: Being in close touch with me for such a long time, you should have known everything about the band. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: looking at or listening to someone or something very carefully
dictionary_examples: On close inspection, you could see that the painting was a fake.
Keep a close watch on the children.
learner_examples: If the parents keep a close watch on their children's activities and friends and advi[s]e them what is right or wrong, this will prevent them from indulging in bad activities. (International English Language Testing System; C2; Hindi)

pos_items.definition: to almost achieve or do something
dictionary_examples: We are close to reaching an agreement.
learner_examples: We were very close to reaching our objective. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: If someone or something is close to a particular state, they are almost in that state.
dictionary_examples: She was close to tears.

pos_items.definition: near in distance

There's a great beach close by.

learner_examples: In my opinion, this debate is rooted in a deeper questioning of society's foundations: some people see society as it stands today as inherently flawed, an amorphous group of people who follow and worship anyone that gives them pleasure. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to describe how a situation seems to be
dictionary_examples: It looks as if it might rain.
It was as though we had known each other for years.
learner_examples: Everything was so familiar, as though he [had] never left the place. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.sense_title: as far as sb is concerned
pos_items.definition: used to show what someone thinks about something
dictionary_examples: As far as I'm concerned, feng shui is a load of rubbish.
As far as our customers are concerned, price is the main consideration.
learner_examples: As far as Laura was concerned, he was the most disgusting man in the world. (First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish)

pos_items.sense_title: as far as sth is concerned
pos_items.definition: used to tell someone what you are talking about
dictionary_examples: As far as money is concerned, we're doing very well.
learner_examples: First of all, I think the Majestic Hotel would be the right location, but I have doubts as far as the costs are concerned. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something must happen before something else can happen
dictionary_examples: I can come as long as I can leave by 4.00.
Bring your friends by all means - just as long as I know how many are coming.
learner_examples: The colo[u]rs I wear are not important, as long as I don't wear any pink clothes. I really dislike that colo[u]r. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that you think something is true, but cannot be sure
dictionary_examples: As far as I know, he's never been in trouble with the police.
learner_examples: As far as I know, accommodation at Camp California is in tents or log cabins. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: until and including this time
dictionary_examples: We haven't needed extra staff as yet, but may do in the future.
No ambulances had as yet managed to get across the river.
learner_examples: I would like to do something about it, but as I can't imagine building anything near my beautiful house (because I'm afraid it would destroy its wonderful harmony), I have no idea as yet how to solve this problem. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: because
dictionary_examples: As it was getting late, I decided to book into a hotel.
You can go first as you're the oldest.
learner_examples: I need it as I have to return it to the library. (Key English Test; A2; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: while or during the time that
dictionary_examples: I saw him as I was coming into the building.
He gets more attractive as he gets older.
learner_examples: After spending two hours searching for her I started to feel desperate, but just as I was ready to give up, the sky got normal again and I found myself [at] my own wedding and she was my wife! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: in the same way
dictionary_examples: He got divorced, (just) as his parents had done years before.
This year, as in previous years, tickets sold very quickly.
As with his earlier movies, the special effects in his latest film are brilliant.
learner_examples: As we expected, we are going to see a movie tonight. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to join two words, phrases, parts of sentences or related statements together
dictionary_examples: Ann and Jim
knives and forks
We kissed and hugged each other.
Tidy up your room. And don't forget to make your bed!
learner_examples: I have got [a] nice bed, [a] mirror, [a] sofa and a table. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak)

pos_items.definition: used to say that one thing happens after another thing
dictionary_examples: I got dressed and had my breakfast.
learner_examples: I get up early [in the] morning and I have breakfast. [T]hen I go to college. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Somali)

pos_items.definition: used when saying or adding numbers
dictionary_examples: It cost a hundred and twenty pounds.
Two and three equals five.
learner_examples: It's about two and a half hours. (Key English Test; A2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used instead of 'to' after some verbs, such as 'try' and 'go'
dictionary_examples: Try and eat something.
I asked him to go and find my glasses.
Wait and see what happens.
learner_examples: I hope [to] go and see Disneyland. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: used after a list of things to show that you could have added other similar things
dictionary_examples: She plays a lot of tennis and squash and so on.
learner_examples: I like watching television, playing [on] the computer, reading book[s] and so on. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used between two words which are the same to make their meaning stronger
dictionary_examples: She spends hours and hours on the telephone.
The sound grew louder and louder.
We laughed and laughed.
learner_examples: The situation became harder and harder. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: used to talk about the job someone has
dictionary_examples: She works as a waitress.
learner_examples: He work[s] in a school as a teacher. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: also
dictionary_examples: Are you going to invite Steve as well?
learner_examples: Dylma goes to school every day and work[s] as well. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in addition to
dictionary_examples: There are soft drinks as well as coffee and tea.
They have lived in the United States as well as Britain.
learner_examples: I like pop as well as country music. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: having a particular use
dictionary_examples: We used the box as a table.
learner_examples: It is very useful because you can use it as a camera. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to compare two things, people, amounts, etc.
dictionary_examples: She'll soon be as tall as her mother.
I can't run as fast as you.
The food here isn't as good as it used to be.
She earns three times as much as I do.
learner_examples: The air isn't as good as in the countryside because of the pollution. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: as much/quickly/soon, etc. as something can happen or be done
dictionary_examples: Please sit down as quickly as possible.
I'll go as soon as possible.
learner_examples: I need it as soon as possible. (Key English Test; A2; Malay)

pos_items.definition: in the way that happens most of the time
dictionary_examples: As usual, James was the last to arrive.
learner_examples: As usual, I'll travel by plane. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: being or appearing to be a particular thing
dictionary_examples: He was dressed as a pirate.
As a young man, he was very lonely.
learner_examples: She was there, standing in front of me, still dressed as a bride, with tears in her eyes. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: at the same time or a very short time after
dictionary_examples: As soon as I saw her, I knew there was something wrong.
learner_examples: As soon as the rain stopped, I called my friend and we all continued walking in the park, and we all enjoyed ourselves. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Georgian)

pos_items.definition: used at the beginning of a sentence to introduce a slightly different subject, but one that is connected in some way
dictionary_examples: I was pleased about the news. As for Emily, well, who cares what she thinks?
learner_examples: As for Chris, he agreed with me to do fifty kilometres on Saturday and stay at the Lakeside Inn. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: because of something
dictionary_examples: Unemployment has risen as a result of the credit crunch.
learner_examples: [O]n more than one oc[c]asion I missed the new releases or arrived late, as a result of trusting the [cinema's] website. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: when considered as a group and not in parts
dictionary_examples: The population as a whole is getting healthier.
learner_examples: To sum up, I can say that the greatest ever invention is the invention of computers, that has affected both indivi[d]uals and society as a whole. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: used to give more information, or to correct something that has been said
dictionary_examples: John plays golf professionally. As a matter of fact, he has just won a big competition.
"So you're from Cambridge?" "No, as a matter of fact, I'm from Bristol."
learner_examples: I think it would be better to choose somewhere outdoors. As a matter of fact, I prefer the open air and the sunlight! (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used to introduce a list or description
dictionary_examples: The main reasons are as follows.
learner_examples: The summary of relevant points and recommendations are as follows: 1. Both of them are located in the centre of town. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: something that you say in order to introduce a surprising fact
dictionary_examples: As it happens, her birthday is the day after mine.
learner_examples: As it happens, I am currrently looking for a computer course for myself and I would like to join one of your courses. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Hebrew)

pos_items.definition: used before a number or amount to show that the number or amount is large
dictionary_examples: As many as 6,000 people may have been infected with the disease.
learner_examples: As many as 90% of them went to [the] cinema on a regular basis in 1990, with the peak of [a] 95% attendance rate taking place in 1996. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Thai)

pos_items.definition: used to say that two things are very different
dictionary_examples: I'm talking about English football, as opposed to European football.
learner_examples: Love is accepting people as they are, being tolerant and giving freedom, as opposed to possessive love, which is what is often - if not always - understood by love. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.sense_title: do sth as you see/think fit
pos_items.definition: to do something that you feel is the right thing to do, although other people might disapprove
dictionary_examples: You must spend the money as you see fit.
learner_examples: Do as you think fit! (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to show that the name of something tells you something about it
dictionary_examples: The Long Room, as its name implies, runs the entire length of the house.
learner_examples: Sour Sweet, as the name implies, is originally a Chinese restaurant. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: as something is now, without changes in it
dictionary_examples: The law as it stands is very unclear.
learner_examples: In my opinion, this debate is rooted in a deeper questioning of society's foundations: some people see society as it stands today as inherently flawed, an amorphous group of people who follow and worship anyone that gives them pleasure. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

learner_examples: As we expected, we are going to see a movie tonight. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: earlier than something or someone
dictionary_examples: two days before the summer holidays
She arrived before me.
You should always wash your hands before meals.
Think hard before accepting the offer.
learner_examples: We will come before 7 o'clock and help you with dinner. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: at a place that you arrive at first when travelling towards another place
dictionary_examples: The hospital is just before the bridge.
learner_examples: Drivers've got often a problem with finding some space and there is another problem - the car park is open just until 8 pm, so the better thin[g] to do is leave a car in car park before the city centre. (First Certificate in English; B2; Czech)

pos_items.definition: in a position in front of someone or something
dictionary_examples: I've never performed this before an audience.

pos_items.definition: in front of someone or something in an order or a list
dictionary_examples: The letter K comes before L in the English alphabet.

pos_items.definition: treated as more important than someone or something
dictionary_examples: They always put the children's needs before their own.
learner_examples: She puts people with their needs before her own comfort, that is why she is successful. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: earlier than the time when something happens
dictionary_examples: He was a teacher before he became famous.
Before he could reach the door, she quickly closed it.
Before we make a decision, does anyone want to say anything else?
learner_examples: I think the notebook is in your bedroom. I was studying there before I left your home. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: in order to avoid something bad happening
dictionary_examples: Put that stick down before you hurt someone!

pos_items.definition: until (the event mentioned)
dictionary_examples: It took a few moments before I realized that he was joking.

pos_items.definition: very soon
dictionary_examples: We'll be there before you know it.
learner_examples: It is a bit dark inside and especially in winter, it is dark before you know it. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: at an earlier time, or on a previous occasion
dictionary_examples: He said he had never seen her before.
I feel as though I've been here before.
learner_examples: My father never b[ought me] any birthday presents before. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: a long period of time before something
dictionary_examples: I was a vegetarian long before I met Sally.
learner_examples: The cups belonged to my family long before I was born and the fact they are [a] part of my family tradition makes them valuable in my eyes. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: when a time or event has happened
dictionary_examples: Shall we go for a walk after breakfast?
We had a chat after the meeting.
Let's get the shopping. After that, we can stop for a coffee.
After a while, I began to like him.
His birthday is exactly a week after mine.
It was so boring, I left after ten minutes.
learner_examples: You can go shopping, eat [a tasty] meal and after that you can go to the disco and dance all night. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: when you have gone past a particular place
dictionary_examples: Turn left after the hotel.
You want the turning on the right just after the police station.
learner_examples: You can go to a wonderful place near here, The Great Falls. This is a very good place because you can [do] extreme sports. It is just after the town, on Main Road. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: following in order
dictionary_examples: H comes after G in the alphabet.

pos_items.definition: following someone or something
dictionary_examples: We ran after him but he escaped.
learner_examples: I ran after the bus and shouted to her 'hurry up!' (Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used to add information that shows that what you have just said is true
dictionary_examples: You can't expect to be perfect - after all, it was only your first lesson.
learner_examples: I stopped talking with my friends, but not [for long] - after all, we are friends. Anyway, I'm planning nice things for the next April 1st. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.sense_title: day after day/year after year, etc.
pos_items.definition: happening every day/year, etc. over a long period
dictionary_examples: We went to the same part of France for our holidays year after year.
learner_examples: And there she was, day after day, walking in the rain... (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: because of something that happened
dictionary_examples: I'll never trust her again after what she did to me.
learner_examples: I really needed those days after what I've been through this spring. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: despite
dictionary_examples: I can't believe he was so rude to you after all the help you've given him!
learner_examples: But, even after earning more in 2001, the women still do not earn as much [as] men on average earned (£20,363) in 1997. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Gujarati)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something happened or was true although you did not expect it to happen or be true
dictionary_examples: Helen couldn't come to the party after all.
learner_examples: Cars still enter the city so there will be pollution after all. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: used when giving someone or something the same name as another person or thing
dictionary_examples: It was called the Biko building, after the famous South African.
learner_examples: I called her Lena after my sister. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: later than someone or something else
dictionary_examples: Hilary got here at midday and Nicholas arrived soon after.
I can't go next week - how about the week after?
learner_examples: Hi Joe, I would love to see the film with you. We must have dinner after. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: at a later time than something else happens
dictionary_examples: Soon/shortly after we joined the motorway, the car started to make a strange noise.
I went to the post office straight/immediately after I left you.
learner_examples: I hope we will meet soon after I come back home. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Romanian)

learner_examples: He work[s] in a school as a teacher. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: also
dictionary_examples: Are you going to invite Steve as well?
learner_examples: Dylma goes to school every day and work[s] as well. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in addition to
dictionary_examples: There are soft drinks as well as coffee and tea.
They have lived in the United States as well as Britain.
learner_examples: I like pop as well as country music. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: having a particular use
dictionary_examples: We used the box as a table.
learner_examples: It is very useful because you can use it as a camera. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to compare two things, people, amounts, etc.
dictionary_examples: She'll soon be as tall as her mother.
I can't run as fast as you.
The food here isn't as good as it used to be.
She earns three times as much as I do.
learner_examples: The air isn't as good as in the countryside because of the pollution. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: as much/quickly/soon, etc. as something can happen or be done
dictionary_examples: Please sit down as quickly as possible.
I'll go as soon as possible.
learner_examples: I need it as soon as possible. (Key English Test; A2; Malay)

pos_items.definition: in the way that happens most of the time
dictionary_examples: As usual, James was the last to arrive.
learner_examples: As usual, I'll travel by plane. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: being or appearing to be a particular thing
dictionary_examples: He was dressed as a pirate.
As a young man, he was very lonely.
learner_examples: She was there, standing in front of me, still dressed as a bride, with tears in her eyes. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: at the same time or a very short time after
dictionary_examples: As soon as I saw her, I knew there was something wrong.
learner_examples: As soon as the rain stopped, I called my friend and we all continued walking in the park, and we all enjoyed ourselves. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Georgian)

pos_items.definition: used at the beginning of a sentence to introduce a slightly different subject, but one that is connected in some way
dictionary_examples: I was pleased about the news. As for Emily, well, who cares what she thinks?
learner_examples: As for Chris, he agreed with me to do fifty kilometres on Saturday and stay at the Lakeside Inn. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: because of something
dictionary_examples: Unemployment has risen as a result of the credit crunch.
learner_examples: [O]n more than one oc[c]asion I missed the new releases or arrived late, as a result of trusting the [cinema's] website. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: when considered as a group and not in parts
dictionary_examples: The population as a whole is getting healthier.
learner_examples: To sum up, I can say that the greatest ever invention is the invention of computers, that has affected both indivi[d]uals and society as a whole. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: used to give more information, or to correct something that has been said
dictionary_examples: John plays golf professionally. As a matter of fact, he has just won a big competition.
"So you're from Cambridge?" "No, as a matter of fact, I'm from Bristol."
learner_examples: I think it would be better to choose somewhere outdoors. As a matter of fact, I prefer the open air and the sunlight! (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used to introduce a list or description
dictionary_examples: The main reasons are as follows.
learner_examples: The summary of relevant points and recommendations are as follows: 1. Both of them are located in the centre of town. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: something that you say in order to introduce a surprising fact
dictionary_examples: As it happens, her birthday is the day after mine.
learner_examples: As it happens, I am currrently looking for a computer course for myself and I would like to join one of your courses. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Hebrew)

pos_items.definition: used before a number or amount to show that the number or amount is large
dictionary_examples: As many as 6,000 people may have been infected with the disease.
learner_examples: As many as 90% of them went to [the] cinema on a regular basis in 1990, with the peak of [a] 95% attendance rate taking place in 1996. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Thai)

pos_items.definition: used to say that two things are very different
dictionary_examples: I'm talking about English football, as opposed to European football.
learner_examples: Love is accepting people as they are, being tolerant and giving freedom, as opposed to possessive love, which is what is often - if not always - understood by love. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.sense_title: do sth as you see/think fit
pos_items.definition: to do something that you feel is the right thing to do, although other people might disapprove
dictionary_examples: You must spend the money as you see fit.
learner_examples: Do as you think fit! (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to show that the name of something tells you something about it
dictionary_examples: The Long Room, as its name implies, runs the entire length of the house.
learner_examples: Sour Sweet, as the name implies, is originally a Chinese restaurant. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: as something is now, without changes in it
dictionary_examples: The law as it stands is very unclear.
learner_examples: In my opinion, this debate is rooted in a deeper questioning of society's foundations: some people see society as it stands today as inherently flawed, an amorphous group of people who follow and worship anyone that gives them pleasure. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to describe how a situation seems to be
dictionary_examples: It looks as if it might rain.
It was as though we had known each other for years.
learner_examples: Everything was so familiar, as though he [had] never left the place. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.sense_title: as far as sb is concerned
pos_items.definition: used to show what someone thinks about something
dictionary_examples: As far as I'm concerned, feng shui is a load of rubbish.
As far as our customers are concerned, price is the main consideration.
learner_examples: As far as Laura was concerned, he was the most disgusting man in the world. (First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish)

pos_items.sense_title: as far as sth is concerned
pos_items.definition: used to tell someone what you are talking about
dictionary_examples: As far as money is concerned, we're doing very well.
learner_examples: First of all, I think the Majestic Hotel would be the right location, but I have doubts as far as the costs are concerned. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something must happen before something else can happen
dictionary_examples: I can come as long as I can leave by 4.00.
Bring your friends by all means - just as long as I know how many are coming.
learner_examples: The colo[u]rs I wear are not important, as long as I don't wear any pink clothes. I really dislike that colo[u]r. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that you think something is true, but cannot be sure
dictionary_examples: As far as I know, he's never been in trouble with the police.
learner_examples: As far as I know, accommodation at Camp California is in tents or log cabins. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: until and including this time
dictionary_examples: We haven't needed extra staff as yet, but may do in the future.
No ambulances had as yet managed to get across the river.
learner_examples: I would like to do something about it, but as I can't imagine building anything near my beautiful house (because I'm afraid it would destroy its wonderful harmony), I have no idea as yet how to solve this problem. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: because
dictionary_examples: As it was getting late, I decided to book into a hotel.
You can go first as you're the oldest.
learner_examples: I need it as I have to return it to the library. (Key English Test; A2; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: while or during the time that
dictionary_examples: I saw him as I was coming into the building.
He gets more attractive as he gets older.
learner_examples: After spending two hours searching for her I started to feel desperate, but just as I was ready to give up, the sky got normal again and I found myself [at] my own wedding and she was my wife! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: in the same way
dictionary_examples: He got divorced, (just) as his parents had done years before.
This year, as in previous years, tickets sold very quickly.
As with his earlier movies, the special effects in his latest film are brilliant.
learner_examples: As we expected, we are going to see a movie tonight. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

learner_examples: As we expected, we are going to see a movie tonight. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: earlier than something or someone
dictionary_examples: two days before the summer holidays
She arrived before me.
You should always wash your hands before meals.
Think hard before accepting the offer.
learner_examples: We will come before 7 o'clock and help you with dinner. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: at a place that you arrive at first when travelling towards another place
dictionary_examples: The hospital is just before the bridge.
learner_examples: Drivers've got often a problem with finding some space and there is another problem - the car park is open just until 8 pm, so the better thin[g] to do is leave a car in car park before the city centre. (First Certificate in English; B2; Czech)

pos_items.definition: in a position in front of someone or something
dictionary_examples: I've never performed this before an audience.

pos_items.definition: in front of someone or something in an order or a list
dictionary_examples: The letter K comes before L in the English alphabet.

pos_items.definition: treated as more important than someone or something
dictionary_examples: They always put the children's needs before their own.
learner_examples: She puts people with their needs before her own comfort, that is why she is successful. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: earlier than the time when something happens
dictionary_examples: He was a teacher before he became famous.
Before he could reach the door, she quickly closed it.
Before we make a decision, does anyone want to say anything else?
learner_examples: I think the notebook is in your bedroom. I was studying there before I left your home. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: in order to avoid something bad happening
dictionary_examples: Put that stick down before you hurt someone!

pos_items.definition: until (the event mentioned)
dictionary_examples: It took a few moments before I realized that he was joking.

pos_items.definition: very soon
dictionary_examples: We'll be there before you know it.
learner_examples: It is a bit dark inside and especially in winter, it is dark before you know it. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: at an earlier time, or on a previous occasion
dictionary_examples: He said he had never seen her before.
I feel as though I've been here before.
learner_examples: My father never b[ought me] any birthday presents before. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: a long period of time before something
dictionary_examples: I was a vegetarian long before I met Sally.
learner_examples: The cups belonged to my family long before I was born and the fact they are [a] part of my family tradition makes them valuable in my eyes. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to introduce an added statement, usually something that is different from what you have said before
dictionary_examples: You can invite Keith to the party, but please don't ask that friend of his.
She's very hard-working but not very imaginative.
She's not only a painter but also a writer.
I think it's true, but then, I'm no expert.
learner_examples: There are eight rooms but the best one is my bedroom, because there are a lot of books. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used before you say why something did not happen or is not true
dictionary_examples: I was going to go to his party, but I was ill.
learner_examples: I'm really sorry I haven't written for so long, but I was very busy last week. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: except
dictionary_examples: Everyone but Andrew knows.
This car has been nothing but trouble - it's always breaking down!
learner_examples: I'm free all days of the week but Monday and Wednesday. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: the number 8
dictionary_examples: She was eight years old when her family moved here.
We've got eight people coming to dinner.
learner_examples: I will arrive at eight in the morning. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: the number 18
dictionary_examples: seventeen, eighteen, nineteen
an eighteen-storey building
learner_examples: I want to sell a bike. It is eighteen years old. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: the number 11
dictionary_examples: nine, ten, eleven, twelve
There are eleven girls in my class and fifteen boys.
learner_examples: I invited ten or eleven friends. (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: 8th written as a word
dictionary_examples: He finished eighth in the race.
Bob's birthday is on the eighth (of June).
learner_examples: I'm free on the eighth of June. (Key English Test; A2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: the number 80
dictionary_examples: seventy, eighty, ninety

learner_examples: The film is a fantasy novel and it [was] written by Tolkien about eighty years ago. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: to be aged between 80 and 89
dictionary_examples: Many of the residents are in their eighties.

pos_items.definition: the years from 1980-1989
dictionary_examples: They moved to Britain in the eighties.
learner_examples: He is a normal man with no special education but he became famous during the eighties as a musician. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: to the degree that
dictionary_examples: The story is based insofar as possible on notes made by Scott himself.
learner_examples: Consequently the cited statement is definitely true but understates its point insofar as it neglects any time horizon. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

learner_examples: I will finish work at five o'clock. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: the number 4

learner_examples: He works four days and has four days off. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: the number 14
dictionary_examples: twelve, thirteen, fourteen, fifteen

learner_examples: Several days ago I had my birthday and I am now fourteen. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: 5th written as a word
dictionary_examples: the fifth floor of the building

learner_examples: This is [the] fifth Harry Potter book. (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: one of five equal parts of something
dictionary_examples: One fifth is the same as 20 percent.

pos_items.definition: the number 50
dictionary_examples: forty, fifty, sixty

learner_examples: There were fifty guests at my party. (Key English Test; A2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: to be aged between 50 and 59
dictionary_examples: He retired when he was still in his fifties.
learner_examples: Despite being in my fifties I am healthy and in good shape. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: the years from 1950-1959
dictionary_examples: Many new towns were built in the fifties.
learner_examples: I love bands from the fifties, sixties, seventies... and most of the radio stations seem to forget that the music has a history and it is always nice to remember past songs, because a good song will always be a good song. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: the number 40
dictionary_examples: thirty, forty, fifty
He looks about forty.
learner_examples: There were about forty people. (Key English Test; A2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to be aged between 40 and 49
dictionary_examples: By the time I'm in my forties, I want to be running my own business.
learner_examples: The man was in his early forties and he looked to be a very important man. (First Certificate in English; B2; Basque)

pos_items.definition: the years from 1940-1949
dictionary_examples: Most of these people were born in the forties.
learner_examples: So, I would like you to consider buying some English comedies, like those Ealing Studios [made] in the late forties and the fifties. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: 4th written as a word
dictionary_examples: My birthday is on the fourth of December.
Daniel finished fourth in the race.
learner_examples: The new art class is in classroom A [o]n the fourth floor. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: the number 100
dictionary_examples: We've driven a/one hundred miles in the last two hours.
"How many children are there in the school?" "About three hundred."
That dress costs hundreds of pounds.
learner_examples: It cost nine hundred yuan at least. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: a lot
dictionary_examples: Hundreds of people wrote in to complain.
learner_examples: When she came back to reality she could see hundreds of people applauding.. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something will happen only after something else happens or is true
dictionary_examples: We'll have the party in the garden if the weather's good.
If anyone rings for me, please tell them I'll be back in the office at 4 o'clock.
We'll deal with that problem if and when it arises.
learner_examples: If you want [me] to, I'll bring you some of my CDs. (Key English Test; A2; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: used to mean always or every time
dictionary_examples: If water is heated to 100°C it turns to steam.
If I don't get enough sleep I get a headache.
learner_examples: If there is a world cup - e.g. football - then I spend more time watching television. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: used to talk about something that might happen
dictionary_examples: If I won the lottery, I'd buy a boat.
What would you do if he moved away?
learner_examples: It would be great if you came to the city. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: whether
dictionary_examples: I wonder if he'll get the job?
Mrs Kramer rang half an hour ago to ask if her cake was ready.
I don't care if he likes it or not - I'm coming!
learner_examples: But let's see if a friend can lend me his notebook, [as] that way I will c[atch] up easily. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used when you give someone advice
dictionary_examples: If I were you, I'd probably go.
I think I'd take the money if I were you.
learner_examples: But you enjoy clubbing and discos, so, if I were you, I would [choose the] city. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak)

pos_items.definition: used to talk about what would/might/could, etc. have happened
dictionary_examples: If we'd had the money, we'd have bought a new car.
If you'd mentioned this earlier, it might not have been necessary to call the doctor.

pos_items.definition: used when you want to say how doing something simple would make it possible to avoid something unpleasant
dictionary_examples: If only she'd listen to what he's saying, I'm sure they could work it out.
learner_examples: If only I had been more careful. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean)

pos_items.definition: used to say what the situation will be if something does not happen
dictionary_examples: I hope to see you there but, if not, I'll call you.
learner_examples: I'm going to paint my bedroom with the pink paint. Remember to put on your old cloth[e]s. If not, your clothes will become pinky and you can't use them anymore. (Key English Test; A2; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: if this is the case
dictionary_examples: It might rain this afternoon. If so, we'll have to have the party indoors.
learner_examples: Let me know if you [can] come, and if so, [whether] you prefer the 15th or 22nd of February. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: used when you offer someone something
dictionary_examples: If you like, I could drive you there.
learner_examples: If you like, we can go to a night club. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to describe how a situation seems to be
dictionary_examples: It looks as if it might rain.
It was as if we had been friends for years.
learner_examples: The sun was up in the sky, there were no clouds and it looked as if it was going to be a wonderful day. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: used when you are about to say something which is surprising compared with what you have just said
dictionary_examples: This is one possible solution to the problem. However, there are others.
There may, however, be other reasons that we don't know about.
learner_examples: I will be very happy to go fishing and swimming in the lake like the last time. However, if you don't want to do it, it's not a problem for me. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to say that it does not make any difference how cold/difficult/slowly, etc.
dictionary_examples: We're not going to get there in time, however fast we drive.
However hungry I am, I never seem to be able to finish off a whole pizza.
If Emma likes something she'll buy it however much it costs.
I'll see you after the show and give you £20 for the tickets, or however much they cost.
learner_examples: We think that we are careful and that we can avoid traffic accidents, but however careful we may be, some other people might be careless and hit us. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: in whatever way
dictionary_examples: However you look at it, it's still a mess.
You can do it however you like, it really doesn't matter.
learner_examples: However you do it, the important part is that you relax. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: the number 1 000 000
dictionary_examples: She got eight million dollars for appearing in that film.
learner_examples: It costs about three million VietNam dong (VND). (Key English Test; A2; Vietnamese)

pos_items.definition: a lot
dictionary_examples: I've seen that film millions of times.
learner_examples: There are millions of things you can do with a computer. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: similar to or in the same way as someone or something
dictionary_examples: She's very much like her mother.
Is Japanese food anything like Chinese?
I've got a sweater just like that.
Her hair was so soft it was like silk.
learner_examples: After the game, we had a barbecue and I met Theresa, a very good-looking girl who is interested in politics, just like me. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: something you say when you want someone to describe someone or something
dictionary_examples: I haven't met him - what's he like?
So what's your new dress like?
learner_examples: What is she like? (Preliminary English Test; B1; Lithuanian)

pos_items.definition: such as
dictionary_examples: She looks best in bright colours, like red and pink.
learner_examples: We have visit[ed] beautiful places like Chile, Patagonia, Iguazu. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean)

pos_items.definition: typical or characteristic of
dictionary_examples: That's just like Maisie to turn up half an hour late to her own party!
It's not like you to be so quiet - are you all right?

pos_items.definition: a lot
dictionary_examples: The band practised like mad before their first concert.
learner_examples: It was raining like mad, so we were wet to the skin. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: doing something a lot or in a fast way
dictionary_examples: We worked like crazy to get everything finished.
learner_examples: My heart was beating like crazy and when the ski-boat started its journey along the blue waves of the sea... (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: very much
dictionary_examples: It's raining like hell out there.
learner_examples: Soon it will be dark, and still pouring down like hell. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: similar to or approximately
dictionary_examples: He paid something like $2000 for his car.
learner_examples: He earns something like £100,000 a week or even more. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: to enjoy something or feel that someone or something is pleasant
dictionary_examples: I like your new haircut.
Do you like fish?
I like it when a book is so good that you can't put it down.
I don't like upsetting people.
He's very well-liked at work.
He likes to spend his evenings in front of the television.
He likes his steak well-done.
learner_examples: I like reading and writing. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that you want something
dictionary_examples: I think I'd like the soup for my starter.
I'd like to go to Moscow.
I would like to say a big thankyou to everyone who's helped to make our wedding such a special occasion!
I'd like to book a seat for tonight's performance.
learner_examples: I would like to talk with people to practise my English. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Mandarin)

pos_items.definition: used to ask someone if they want something
dictionary_examples: Would you like a drink?
Would you like to eat now?
learner_examples: Would you like to come? (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Kurdish)

pos_items.definition: used when you offer someone something
dictionary_examples: If you like, I could drive you there.
learner_examples: If you like, we can go to a night club. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: as if
dictionary_examples: It looks like I'm going to be in the office until late tonight.
It sounds to me like you ought to change jobs.
You look like you've just got out of bed!
She acts like she's stupid!
learner_examples: It [sound]s like your trousers are really pretty, I would like to see them soon. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: things that you do and do not like
dictionary_examples: What are your top five likes and dislikes?
learner_examples: The teacher asked about our families, friends, [and] likes and dislikes and [then] the lesson finished. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used between possibilities, or before the last in a list of possibilities
dictionary_examples: Would you like tea or coffee?
Is that a boy or a girl?
You can have beer, wine or mineral water.
It was either 1982 or 1983 - I can't remember which.
There were ten or twelve people in the room.
It will only take three or four days.
learner_examples: I like to eat pasta or pizza, but I'm easy about food, I can eat anything. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French)

pos_items.definition: used after a negative verb to mean not one thing and also not another
dictionary_examples: Tim doesn't eat meat or fish.
She doesn't have a telephone or a computer.
learner_examples: OH! and please don't wear jeans or white clothes. (Key English Test; A2; Thai)

pos_items.definition: used to express the possibility that something might not happen
dictionary_examples: Are you going to reply or not?
I still don't know whether she's coming or not.
learner_examples: Are [you] busy or not that day? (Key English Test; A2; Singhalese)

pos_items.definition: used to give someone a warning or advice
dictionary_examples: You should eat more, or you'll make yourself ill.
learner_examples: She called "Bill, come here or you'll be in trouble". (Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: used to change or correct something you have said
dictionary_examples: We told the truth, or most of it.
Rosalind, or Roz to her friends, took the initiative.
Things have been going quite well recently. Or they were, up until two days ago.
learner_examples: She is the one [who goes] around with all Rebecca's secrets. Or, almost all the secrets. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: approximately
dictionary_examples: They raised two hundred pounds or so for charity.
learner_examples: After an hour or so they changed the flight and new people came, then he realised that his suitcase was lost. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: used to say what will happen if another thing does not happen
dictionary_examples: We must be there by six, or else we'll miss the beginning.
learner_examples: [He] told me to hurry up, or else I would miss my bus. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to give a reason for something you have said
dictionary_examples: She must love him or she wouldn't have stayed with him all these years.

pos_items.definition: used to show a very small number, usually one or two
dictionary_examples: I'd like to say a word or two about loyalty.
learner_examples: Many fathers do not realize what they are missing by not demanding the privilege of staying at home with the child, at least for a month or two. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: used to compare two different things or situations
dictionary_examples: He talks to her all the time, or else he completely ignores her.
learner_examples: Naturally Olivia's leaving affects Douglas, though not as strongly as one could have expected or else he simply does not show it. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: used to explain that the words you are using do not have their usual meaning
dictionary_examples: That was our accommodation, so to speak.
learner_examples: In those cases, travelling turns into a sort of alienation, so to speak. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something is the reason why something else happens
dictionary_examples: I was tired so I went to bed.
Greg had some money so he bought a bike.
My knee started hurting so I stopped running.
I was lost so I bought a street map.
learner_examples: I'm going to change my school, so I have to sell all my books. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used at the beginning of a sentence to connect it with something that was said or happened previously
dictionary_examples: So, there I was standing at the edge of the road with only my underwear on ...
So, just to finish what I was saying earlier...
So, who do you think is going to win the election?
So, here we are again - just you and me.
So that's what he does when I'm not around!
So we leave on the Thursday and get back the next Tuesday, is that right?
learner_examples: I remember you said that you want to help me. So, can you buy the items for me and then I pay you? (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: in order to make something happen or be possible
dictionary_examples: He put his glasses on so that he could see the television better.
I deliberately didn't have lunch so (that) I would be hungry tonight.
Leave the keys out so (that) I remember to take them with me.
learner_examples: Could you please give me some extra exercises so that I can cover the work I missed? (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to refer to something or someone that can be seen or pointed to
dictionary_examples: Did you know that woman in the post office?
How much are those shoes?

pos_items.definition: used to refer to something or someone that has already been talked about or seen
dictionary_examples: Where's that pen gone?
She lives in that house by the bus station.
learner_examples: I like that place be[cause] I like swim[m]ing in [the] sea. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to show that what you have just said is only an example from a larger group of things
dictionary_examples: They sell souvenirs, postcards, that sort of thing.
learner_examples: I also enjoy using new clothes for the first time, but I prefer buying other stuff like electronic devices or that sort of thing. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used after some verbs, nouns, and adjectives to introduce a new part of a sentence
dictionary_examples: She said (that) she'd collect it for me after work.
Is it true (that) she's gone back to teaching?
We'll be there at about 7.30, provided/providing (that) there's a suitable train.
It was so dark (that) I couldn't see anything.
learner_examples: It's true that I bought a mobile phone. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: because of or for this reason
dictionary_examples: The course is good in that it provides a very practical training.
learner_examples: Nowadays it is widely argued that professional sports are damaging to people's health in that they involve gruelling training sessions as an integral part of the occupation. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: used to refer to something that can be seen or pointed to
dictionary_examples: What's that in the corner?
I'd like some of those.
That looks heavy.

pos_items.definition: used to refer to something that has already been talked about or seen
dictionary_examples: If you do that, you'll be sorry.
I don't think you should put up with that.
You can't wear those to a wedding.
learner_examples: After that we have a break. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to make a connection with an earlier statement
dictionary_examples: My usual train was cancelled. That's why I'm so late.
She tricked him, and that's what really upset him.
learner_examples: I decided [not to] play football any more! That is why I want to sell them. (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: used instead of 'who' or 'which' at the beginning of a relative clause
dictionary_examples: Have you eaten all the cake that I made yesterday?
learner_examples: I like my old-fashioned blue jeans, [and] the old shoes that I always use. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used for saying that other similar things are included or that the whole of a situation is considered
dictionary_examples: He told us about his school and all that.
We decided to stay in bed, with it being a holiday and all that.
learner_examples: I really enjoy shopping for clothes, but not only for clothes, also for things like earrings and all that! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something has ended
dictionary_examples: Well that's it then, we've finished.
I think that's it for now - I'll email you about the other project next week.
learner_examples: Well, that's it. Good luck and have a good time. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something is correct
dictionary_examples: You need to push the two pieces together. That's it.

pos_items.definition: used to express a reaction to something
dictionary_examples: I didn't know she'd been so ill. That's terrible.
Turn the engine on, then put the car in gear. That's right.
Smile for the camera. That's more like it.

pos_items.definition: used to refer to events or experiences in the past
dictionary_examples: That was before we had a car.
learner_examples: That was when I went to live in Barcelona by myself in a student residence. (First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something has happened or a decision has been made and there is nothing more to say or do
dictionary_examples: I won't agree to it and that's that.
learner_examples: That's it and that's that!" as they say in the "Sorbits-advertis[e]ment" Bye! (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: used to correct something you have said or give more information about something
dictionary_examples: Everybody was at the meeting, well everyone except Jeanne, that is.
learner_examples: All in all, the students who participated in this programme were quite happy and had an enjoyable time there, except for some, that is. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: different things which are not very important
dictionary_examples: "What are you doing today?" "Oh, just this and that."
learner_examples: He used to call his friends daily, chat about this and that, release the tension through silly jokes, even go out with them once in a while. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used when describing the size, amount, or state of something or someone
dictionary_examples: She's too young to walk that far.
It wasn't (all) that good.
learner_examples: My English isn't that bad, actually I have been taught English in school for six years. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: 3rd written as a word
dictionary_examples: the third road on the right
the third time
"What's the date today?" "It's the third."
She came third in the race.
learner_examples: If you come from [the] Dorchester side, you will see some houses and the third [one] is mine. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Slovak)

pos_items.definition: one of three equal parts of something
dictionary_examples: He cut the cake into thirds.
learner_examples: Two thirds said we should film [the students] playing football. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: the number 30
dictionary_examples: twenty, thirty, forty

learner_examples: It's thirty years old. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: to be aged between 30 and 39
dictionary_examples: More women are having their first child in their thirties.
learner_examples: He was in his thirties and really handsome. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: the years from 1930-1939
dictionary_examples: They moved to Paris in the thirties.
learner_examples: In the beginning of the thirties in [the] USA the film industry [grew]. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: the number 1000
dictionary_examples: There were more than three thousand people at the concert.
learner_examples: It will cost only two thousand pounds. (Key English Test; A2; Baluchi)

pos_items.definition: a lot
dictionary_examples: She tried on thousands of dresses but didn't like any of them

pos_items.definition: used with a verb to make an infinitive
dictionary_examples: She agreed to help.
We were starting to feel cold.
I don't know what to do.
Can you tell me how to get there?
It's not likely to happen.
He told me to wait.
Did anyone ask Daniel to book the room?
There's an awful lot of work to be done.
I need to eat something first.
learner_examples: She likes to go shopping with friend[s]. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Bulgarian)

pos_items.definition: used to give the purpose of something or the reason for doing something
dictionary_examples: I'm going there to see my sister.
This tool is used to make holes in leather.
learner_examples: Dear Robbie, I'm writing to tell you some information about what we['re going to] do. (Key English Test; A2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used instead of repeating a verb clause
dictionary_examples: "Are you going tonight?" "I'm certainly hoping to."
"Would you like to come?" "I'd love to."
learner_examples: Yes, I'd love to. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that you could have said something in a much stronger way
dictionary_examples: We were surprised, to say the least.
learner_examples: You get slightly bored, to say the least. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: if you do this, or if this is done
dictionary_examples: They want to build a completely new school, but to do so would cost far too much.

pos_items.definition: If you have time, money, etc. to spare, you have more than you need.
dictionary_examples: I arrived at the station with more than an hour to spare.
learner_examples: I even started to do the shopping on the Net, and I think this is the perfect solution for the busines[s] woman with family and little time to spare. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: If there is a particular amount of time to go, that time remains.
dictionary_examples: There are only two weeks of term to go.

pos_items.definition: used to talk about a place or an event where someone goes
dictionary_examples: We went to Prague last year.

He went up to a complete stranger and started talking.
learner_examples: I like go[ing] to London. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to say 'before' the hour when you are saying what time it is
dictionary_examples: It's five to three.

pos_items.definition: used to give information about periods of time
dictionary_examples: The museum is open from Tuesday to Saturday.
learner_examples: We have the class on Monday from 9 o'clock to 10 o'clock in the morning. (Key English Test; A2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: used to show who receives something or experiences an action

Give the gun to me.
Anna was speaking to her mother on the phone.
I lent my bike to my brother.
Who's the letter addressed to?
learner_examples: Please bring it to me tomorrow, because I have to return it to my brother. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to show the position of someone or something

I had my back to them, so I couldn't see what they were doing.
John's standing to the left of Adrian in the photo.

pos_items.definition: used to say who is treated in a particular way or who or what is affected by something

pos_items.definition: used to show a relationship with someone

pos_items.definition: used to compare two things

learner_examples: I prefer homemade food to re[s]taurant meals. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian)

pos_items.definition: until a particular time, state or level is reached
dictionary_examples: It's only two weeks to Christmas.

She nursed me back to health.

pos_items.definition: used to say where something is fastened or connected

learner_examples: My mouth became so dry that my tongue stuck to my palate. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: used in phrases which show a range
dictionary_examples: There must have been thirty to thirty-five people there.

pos_items.definition: up to the present time
dictionary_examples: This is her best work to date.
learner_examples: I enclose a copy of my curriculum vitae, which will give you further details about my career to date. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that you are giving your own opinion

pos_items.definition: saying or showing the opposite
