learner_examples: I can read and understand French, though I don't speak [it] very well. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used especially at the end of a sentence, to add a fact or opinion to what you have just said
dictionary_examples: Okay, I'll come to the party. I'm not staying late though.
learner_examples: It would be fun to work with you. There are a few things we should think about though. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: the number 0
dictionary_examples: Five, four, three, two, one, zero.
learner_examples: Can you [bring] me my laptop, because I have to do [some] homework on it - if I don't do this I will [get] a zero. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: the temperature at which water freezes in degrees centigrade
dictionary_examples: The temperature is expected to drop to ten degrees below zero tonight.
learner_examples: We have to learn that [it] is not natural for a lion [to live] in a country where, in winter, [the] temperature can fall below zero. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: during the time that, or at the same time as
dictionary_examples: I read it while you were drying your hair.
While I was in Italy, I went to see Alessandro.
I thought I heard him come in while we were having dinner.
"I'm going to the post office." "While you're there, can you get me some stamps?"
learner_examples: My mother gave it to me yesterday evening while I was playing [a] comp[u]ter game. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used to compare two different facts or situations
dictionary_examples: He gets fifty thousand pounds a year while I get only twenty!
Tom is very confident while Katy is shy and quiet.
learner_examples: In Italy, weddings [are] very traditional! The girls [wear] a long, white dress, while the boys, normally, [wear] dark [clothes]. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: despite the fact that; although
dictionary_examples: While I accept that he's not perfect in many respects, I do actually quite like the man.
While I fully understand your point of view, I do also have some sympathy with Michael's.
learner_examples: While it is true that everyone should have a computer at home because it is useful, on the other hand hardly anybody [can] afford [one]. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: a length of time
dictionary_examples: I only stayed for a short while.
You were there a while, weren't you?
"When did that happen?" "Oh, it was a while ago".
After a while, Roberto came back inside.
I haven't seen him for a while.
I'll be fine in a while.
learner_examples: After a while, a girl invited me to play darts with her and her friends. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: a long time
dictionary_examples: I hadn’t seen Rebecca in quite a while.
It took quite a while to clean out the garage.
learner_examples: But although I have what you could call "simple" tastes, it takes me quite a while to decide what to buy. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: sometimes but not often
dictionary_examples: We do go to the beach once in a while.
learner_examples: She did not say very much except for "oh" and "yes, yes" every once in a while. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: If it is worth your while doing something, it is useful or enjoyable to do it.
dictionary_examples: It's worth your while taking out travel insurance before you travel.
It isn't worth my while going all that way just for one day.
learner_examples: It would be worth your while to visit the country's capital Havana, and don't forget to go into the Folklore Museum and Library, the War Museum and the Archeological [Museum]. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: the number 20
dictionary_examples: nineteen, twenty, twenty-one
space for twenty people

pos_items.definition: to be aged between 20 and 29
dictionary_examples: Most of the staff are in their twenties.
learner_examples: Teenagers and people in their twenties will enjoy themselves in the atmosphere of the rock-café. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: the years from 1920-1929
dictionary_examples: I love the fashions of the twenties.
learner_examples: You can find the car [that] won the first car race in the world, [and] lost movies from the twenties. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: the number 2
dictionary_examples: They've got two houses.
I spent two years in Ethiopia.
It's two o'clock.
He'll be two (years old) in February.
learner_examples: I go to college two days per week. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to talk about a small number of something
dictionary_examples: I may bring a friend or two.
learner_examples: I also refused to eat any meal a day or two before the test but my mother made me, she said I needed the energy to be happy and celebrate afterwards. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Thai)

pos_items.definition: to have difficulty making a decision
dictionary_examples: I'm in two minds about accepting his offer.
learner_examples: If you are in two minds about having to share your room with someone else, there you can easily rent a studio apartment close to the college, which is situated in the centre of the city. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian)

pos_items.definition: used to ask at what time something happened or will happen
dictionary_examples: "I did tell you about it." "When? I don't remember."
When's your birthday?
When did he leave?
learner_examples: When are you coming [to] my house? (Key English Test; A2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: used to say at what time something happened or will happen
dictionary_examples: I found it when I was cleaning out the cupboards.
We'll go when you're ready.
She was only twenty when she had her first baby.
He was quite shocked when I told him.
learner_examples: I'll ring you when I arrive. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to say something that is surprising after what has already been said
dictionary_examples: He says he hasn't got any money when in fact he's got thousands of dollars in his account.
I don't understand how he can say that everything's fine when it's so obvious that it's not.
Why is she training to be a teacher when she doesn't even like children?
How can you say you don't like something when you've never even tried it!
learner_examples: In your advertisement it was said that I would find stars and artists from around the world, when, in fact, they were from only six countries. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.sense_title: when it comes to sth/doing sth
pos_items.definition: used to introduce a new idea that you want to say something about
dictionary_examples: When it comes to baking cakes, she's an expert.
learner_examples: But when it comes to computers, they just impose some knowledge on students, without any interaction. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used to ask about the place or position of someone or something
dictionary_examples: Where does he live?
Where are my car keys?
"I put them on your desk." "Where? I can't see them."
Where did you put my umbrella?
learner_examples: Where is the college? (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Akan)

pos_items.definition: what someone thinks about you, how they expect you to behave, and how they are likely to behave
dictionary_examples: She said she will never leave her husband, so now at least I know where I stand.

pos_items.definition: what your opinion is about something
dictionary_examples: We asked the head teacher where he stood on the wearing of jewellery in school.
learner_examples: From where I stand, some action must be taken urgently because the problems are constantly exacerbating. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: at, in or to a place or position
dictionary_examples: I've been meaning to ask you where you get your hair cut.
I like to have him next to me where I can keep an eye on him.
learner_examples: I need to know where I can study French. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Slovak)

pos_items.definition: used when referring to a particular stage in a process or activity

learner_examples: We've come to a point where we have forgotten how to read or talk to each other. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

dictionary_examples: I won't call you unless there are any problems.
You can't get a job unless you've got experience.
Unless you call me to say you're not coming, I'll see you at the theatre.

pos_items.definition: continuing to happen before a particular time or event and then stopping
dictionary_examples: I'm staying here until the end of June.
The show will be on until the end of the month.
I was working until past midnight.
learner_examples: I don't go to college every day. I go only on Tuesday until 1.00 p.m. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Kurdish)

pos_items.definition: as far as
dictionary_examples: Carry on until the traffic lights and then turn right.
learner_examples: You have to [stay on] the train until Charles DE GAULLE Etoile station. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: not before a particular time or event
dictionary_examples: We didn't eat until past midnight.
It doesn't open until 7:00.
learner_examples: Two weeks ago I rec[ei]ved your letter but I couldn't answer you until now. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: continuing to happen before a particular time or event and then stopping

learner_examples: I had always wanted to travel by plane to another country but I [di]dn't have the op[p]ortunity until I was eleven years old. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: as far as

learner_examples: On the second day, we cycled [for] approximately 4 hours until we reached a beautiful castle. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: every time or any time
dictionary_examples: Whenever I go there they seem to be out.
learner_examples: I read whenever I can, specially at night. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: every time it is possible
dictionary_examples: I try to use olive oil whenever possible.
learner_examples: My friends have always regarded me as a cheerful, active girl, who is glad to help out whenever possible. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: every time or any time
dictionary_examples: "Will it be okay if I do it tomorrow?" "Sure, whenever."
Do it in a spare moment at the weekend or whenever - it really doesn't matter.

pos_items.definition: in or to any or every place
dictionary_examples: You can sit wherever you like.
Wherever you choose to live there are always going to be disadvantages.
learner_examples: I will be able to take you wherever you want in [a] matter of minutes. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: every time it is possible
dictionary_examples: Wherever possible I use honey instead of sugar.
We try to sell local fruit and vegetables wherever possible.
learner_examples: We can work together [in a] number of ways, for e[xample], we can plant trees wherever possible and we can place bins [i]n the necessary areas which will help the public to dispose [of] waste items. (International English Language Testing System; B2; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: used especially in reporting questions and when expressing doubt to mean if
dictionary_examples: I wasn't sure whether you'd like it.
She asked me whether I was interested in working for her.
I doubt whether it'll work.
It all depends on whether or not she's got the time.
learner_examples: It's very expensive and I'm so broke that I don't know whether I can afford to buy one. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: used to talk about a choice between two or more possibilities
dictionary_examples: I'm going, whether she likes it or not.
Someone's got to tell her, whether it's you or me.
Let's face it - you're going to be late whether you go by bus or train.
learner_examples: I don't know whether to stay or to go. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: up until now
dictionary_examples: I haven't spoken to her yet.
He hasn't finished yet.
"Are you ready?" "Not yet - wait a moment."
learner_examples: I haven't seen the sea yet. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: now or as early as this time
dictionary_examples: I don't want to go home yet.
learner_examples: I don't need it yet because my parents gave me a new computer for my birthday. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: the best or worst, etc. until now
dictionary_examples: Of all the songs I've heard tonight, that's the best yet.
That was my worst exam yet.
learner_examples: And that was my worst experience yet. (First Certificate in English; B2; Lithuanian)

pos_items.definition: again after something has happened or been done many times before
dictionary_examples: The bus was late yet again.
learner_examples: Tom, thank you so much yet again for your interest. This talk is very important to me and to count on you is an honour for our college. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: from now and for a particular period of time in the future
dictionary_examples: She won't be back for a long time yet.
Our holiday isn't for weeks yet.
learner_examples: It's a fact that everybody knows that living in Poland is not easy now and it won't be for a long time yet. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to show that you are surprised or annoyed that something is being repeated or increased
dictionary_examples: He's given us yet more work to do.
learner_examples: The awe-inspiring view of the park must not be destroyed for yet another building. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to say there is still a possibility that something will happen
dictionary_examples: He may win yet.
learner_examples: Weakened, the tunnel could yet crumble and fall at any time. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: to not have done something that was expected before this time
dictionary_examples: They have yet to make a decision.
learner_examples: But she had yet to inform her fiancé. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: until and including this time
dictionary_examples: We haven't needed extra staff as yet, but may do in the future.

learner_examples: I would like to do something about it, but as I can't imagine building anything near my beautiful house (because I'm afraid it would destroy its wonderful harmony), I have no idea as yet how to solve this problem. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to connect two words, phrases, or clauses when the second part adds something surprising to the first part
